body:
The players arrived at Lasker Rink in Central Park on Saturday morning with the help of wheelchairs, walkers and crutches. Many had to be helped into their pads and then lifted into the bucket seats of narrow aluminum sleds with skate-blades on the bottom.
 
Dragging them to the edge of the rink and lifting them onto the ice required real
title: CITY ROOM; Young and Disabled, and Scoring Goals Just Like the Pros

body:
Diana Elkind and Chad Paul Maron were married Saturday by Robert S. Smith, an associate judge on the New York State Court of Appeals, at the Battery Gardens Restaurant in Manhattan.
 
Ms. Elkind, 31, is a special assistant attorney general in the New York State Office of the Attorney General in Manhattan. She graduated from the University
title: Diana Elkind, Chad Maron

body: ASBURY PARK, N.J. — I’m riding down Kingsley, looking for a place to park. With the crowds at Convention Hall, the Stone Pony and the Wonder Bar , there are no spots left on this oceanfront stretch. I’m here to see the roller-derby championship, three weeks after Hurricane Sandy ripped through and devoured the boardwalk.
title: Down the Shore, The Lost and the Found

title: Down the Shore, The Lost and the Found

body: SPETTELL--Claire M.,(nee Roth) of Brooklyn, died suddenly on Tuesday, December 4, at age 84. A devoted Brooklyn Dodgers fan, she rode the trolley to Ebbets Field countless times as a teenager. With her beloved husband Herb, who died in 1994, she raised seven children, who loved and admired her deeply. Adored by her nine grandchildren, she in turn
title: Paid Notice: Deaths SPETTELL, CLAIRE M.

author: E-mail: powellm@nytimes.com; Twitter: @powellnyt
body:
It was a munificent gift, just superb.
 
 John A. Paulson , the multibillionaire owner of a hedge fund with income taxed at a rate less than that of most New York City schoolteachers, stepped forward and showered $100 million on Central Park. About half of his money will go to the park’s Conservancy, which moonlights as an investment
title: GOTHAM; Central Park Gets More, While the City’s Poorer Parks, Well, They Just Get By

author: E-mail: powellm@nytimes.com; Twitter: @powellnyt
body: She is not one of New York's Grande Dame parks, those Olmstead beauties with Victorian park houses, manicured lawns, rolling hills and forest glades. She lacks the high-stepping strut of Central Park and the hipster slouch of Prospect Park. And she has no Daddy Warbucks conservancy to shower her in gilt and so pay for a revitalizing face-lift.
title: GOTHAM; In Queens, An Oasis Neglected By the City

body: TO find the head professional at the Marine Park Golf Course in Brooklyn, look for a flamboyant outfit of plaids and pastels, and follow the smoke. You will most likely spot him over on the driving range, enjoying a cigar, bantering with players and fixing swings. He is Hunter Watkins, 41, and he mastered golf by playing the guitar. A veteran of
title: CHARACTER STUDY; Guiding Golfers to Rock Their Shots

body: GEORGE R. BROADHEAD, a retired newspaper executive and Marine Corps veteran, has lived in Beverly Hills and Manhattan Beach, Calif., and Greenwich, Conn., among many other places. The place he is choosing to spend his retirement, though, is the place where he grew up: Gerritsen Beach, Brooklyn .That doesn't mean Mr. Broadhead, who is the president
title: LIVING IN | GERRITSEN BEACH, BROOKLYN; The Art of Hiding in Plain Sight

body: When dark smoke rose from a manhole outside Trump Tower in Manhattan on Monday afternoon, it looked like a sign of the sort of trouble that Consolidated Edison has dreaded for the last three weeks. With the temperature hovering near 90 degrees, electrical cables had started to burn beneath the pavement at the intersection of Fifth Avenue and 56th
title: At Con Ed, the Managers Are Tasked With Repairs

body: At first glance, the urban jungle of New York might seem an inhospitable place for golf. But look again. There go two guys, clubs draped over their shoulders, hustling across West 34th Street and into Pennsylvania Station. A teenager rides the subway on a summer weekday to a nine-hole course in the Bronx, trading in his backpack for a golf bag.
title: ON PAR; Concrete Jungle, but an Oasis Is Never Far Away

body: I moved to New York City on a lark. No job, no girlfriend, just a healthy dose of big-city wanderlust and a curiosity about the city's mythical ownership of pickup basketball. Were its legendary courts just New York hype? Also, as someone who imagines himself a baller, would my skills stand up in the street? This impromptu adventure did not thrill
title: 'I Got Next'

body: For much of the past century, Brooklyn was the Rodney Dangerfield of boroughs, known for its blue-collar style, for its funny accent and, of course, for getting no respect. Then came the brownstone homesteaders and the bohemian pioneers. They turned lunch-bucket warrens in Park Slope, Dumbo and Williamsburg into glamorous destinations, drawing a
title: As Brooklyn Gentrifies, Some Neighborhoods Are Being Left Behind

body: RADIOLI--Louis A.,on June 29, 2012. Retired Professor of Civil Engineering at the City University of New York. Proud WWII US Army Veteran. Beloved husband of Irene (nee Nadotti). Loving father of Mary Ann Radioli-Samaha and her husband Jeff, Paul Radioli and his wife Alcira, and the late Veronica Radioli. Cherished grandfather of Kristina Samaha,
title: Paid Notice: Deaths RADIOLI, LOUIS A.

body: Suddenly, Charles Barron has regained the ability to shock. The New York political world had long ago become accustomed to the incendiary words of Mr. Barron, a confrontational onetime Black Panther turned three-term City Councilman. His more outrageous remarks over the years, from calling Thomas Jefferson a pedophile to likening Gaza to a
title: In Brooklyn, a Longtime Provocateur Surges in a Primary Race for Congress

body: GEE-SETO--Jean, suddenly on May 23, 2012. Insurance Broker for Harold Lee & Sons, Inc. Beloved wife of Shew Ming Seto. Loving mother of Jennifer Mei-Fong Seto and the late Michael Kin-Keung Seto. Cherished sister of four. Funeral Saturday, 9:45am from the Marine Park Funeral Home, 3024 Quentin Rd., Brooklyn. Interment, Evergreen Cemetery.
title: Paid Notice: Deaths GEE, SETO, JEAN

body: The conundrum that Samuel I. Schwartz, the traffic engineering expert, faced was this: How could the already jam-packed streets in the heart of Brooklyn accommodate thousands of extra cars filled with fans traveling to a basketball arena and desperately searching for parking? His answer, revealed on Tuesday to a panel of Brooklyn officials with all
title: Arena Traffic Plan Cuts Parking Slots by Half

body: It has been nearly a quarter-century since Roy Fox had a regular salary. He is not a lottery winner or the recipient of some grand family fortune. He is, in short, the type of person who long ago would have been priced out by New York's ever-climbing housing market. But for more than two decades, Mr. Fox, a retired radio host who earns a modest
title: For Stewards of Historic Homes, No Salary but Unbeatable Rent

body: FRANKLIN--Sylvia, (nee Kletz), on March 6, 2012. Director of Membership Services at Century Club NYC. Beloved companion of Lau Barbera. Cherished aunt of Joseph Kletz. Visitation at the Marine Park Funeral Home 3024 Quentin Road, Brooklyn, Thursday, 6-9pm. Interment will be at St. Casimir Cemetery, Chicago, IL.
title: Paid Notice: Deaths FRANKLIN, SYLVIA

body: GaNUN--Francis Gordon, on March 1, 2012. Beloved husband of Mary Ellen (nee Craven). Loving father of Frank and Teresa, Mary Jo and William, Robert and Patricia, Matthew and Kathleen and Timothy and Lisa. Dear brother of Timothy and the late Joan Kirby. Cherished grandfather of Lauren, Brian, James, Peter, Mary Ellen, Jack, Patrick, Cailtlin, Jane,
title: Paid Notice: Deaths GANUN, FRANCIS GORDON
